awd_titl_txt: Travel and Registration Support for Computer Aided Verification 2016
awd_abstract_narration: This award will support student travel to the 28th International Conference on Computer Aided Verification(CAV). The conference will be held in Toronto, Canada on July 17-23 2016. Supporting student travel to attend professional conferences and workshops is a very important mission of the NSF. Verification technology is being rapidly deployed in a variety of areas both in academic research as well as in industrial systems. Thus the broader significance and importance includes fostering the next generation of researchers in this research area, as well as providing international experiences to build a globally-aware workforce. In particular, students will have the opportunity to learn state-of-the-art methodologies, be exposed to novel techniques, and interact with senior researchers in their areas of expertise.

por.por_cntn:
Thie project provided support for students to attend CAV 2016. CAV 2016 was the 28th in a series dedicated to the advancement of the theory and practice of computer-aided formal analysis methods for hardware and software systems. The conference covered the spectrum from theoretical results to concrete applications, with an emphasis on practical verification tools and the algorithms and techniques that are needed for their implementation. CAV 2016 was held on July 17-23, 2016, in Toronto, Canada.  


NSF awarded $15000 which were spent to support travel and registration of 13 graduate students. The students who presented a paper at the conference,or who coauthored a paper, were given priority by the selection committee. The selection was coordinated with the organizers of the Verification Mentoring Workshop (colocated with CAV), which also sponsored student participation at the conference. 


We invited the students to describe what they expect from  the conference. We present here some selected answers:


"This will be my first time presenting at a conference, which is an invaluable experience for me to acquire for my future as a researcher and academic. Besides honing my presentation skills, it will allow me to receive comments on my work and ideas of directions to pursue in the future. I also wish to obtain a broader view of the field of computer-aided verification and familiarize myself with the different topics that are being researched in the area. Finally, the conference will be an opportunity to come into contact and interact with fellow researchers, which can be a source of new ideas and future collaborations."


"Attending the conference would be a wonderful opportunity to meet fellow students and researchers, learn about ongoing research, and explore directions for future work as I think about a PhD thesis topic.  And CAV 2016 would be my first time presenting a paper at a conference!"


"Besides getting to present our really cool paper, I want to connect with other bright researchers working on related problems and network with all these people whose papers I've been citing."


"This will be my first experience presenting a paper at a main conference. Aside from the benefit of presenting my work, I hope that I can talk to other researchers interested in my work to get new ideas for future directions."
